#summary Opening existing projects in KiCAD

Install [http://www.lis.inpg.fr/realise_au_lis/kicad/ KiCAD] by downloading and running the installer.  Under Ubuntu, KiCAD is in the _universe_ repository and can be installed with `sudo apt-get -y install kicad`.  Under Fedora, KiCAD is in the _RPM Fusion_ repository and can be installed with `sudo yum install kicad`.  [SettingUpUbuntuLinux Ubuntu] and [SettingUpFedoraLinux Fedora] install instructions are [ available].

Run `KiCAD.exe` through the shortcut created on your desktop or in the _Start Menu_.  Under Linux, the shortcut will be under *Applications* -> *Programming* -> *kicad*.

Click *File*, then *Open*, then find the `.pro` KiCAD Project File and click *Open*.

  http://opendous.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/Pictures/KiCAD_Tutorial-OpenFiles-1.jpg

Click the *Eeschema* button to start the schematic editor.

  http://opendous.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/Pictures/KiCAD_Tutorial-OpenFiles-2.jpg

While in the Schematic Editor, use your mouse wheel to zoom in and out to view the schematic.  KiCAD is heavily reliant on a wheel mouse.  Zooming is critical to using KiCAD.

  http://opendous.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/Pictures/KiCAD_Tutorial-OpenFiles-3.jpg

To start the PCB editor, you can click the *PCBnew* button in either *Eeschema*, the Schematic Editor, or through the main KiCAD program.

  http://opendous.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/Pictures/KiCAD_Tutorial-OpenFiles-4.jpg

While in the Layout Editor, *PCBnew*, use your mouse wheel to zoom in and out to view the layout.  Once again, KiCAD is heavily reliant on a wheel mouse.

  http://opendous.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/Pictures/KiCAD_Tutorial-OpenFiles-5.jpg
